title: 🦸satoshi-nakamoto
desc: *(under construction)*  SATOSHI NAKAMOTO Satoshi Nakamoto is the pseudonymou

msgs.text: *(under construction)* SATOSHI NAKAMOTO Satoshi Nakamoto is the pseudonymous creator(s) of Bitcoin. His/their final public correspondence was a post on the bitcointalk.org forum on 12/12/2010: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=2228.msg29479#msg29479 Satoshi’s final known private correspondence was from an April 26, 2011 email to Gavin Andresen. He wrote: "I wish you wouldn't keep talking about me as a mysterious shadowy figure, the press just turns that into a pirate currency angle. Maybe instead make it about the open source project and give more credit to your dev contributors; it helps motivate them." Theories as to why Satoshi disappeared: https://news.bitcoin.com/satoshis-final-messages-leave-tantalizing-clues-to-his-disappearance/ What we do know is that if Satoshi did reveal himself, he would have to sign the Genesis Block and create a verifiable PGP message to prove his/her identity.

-
*Persons proposed to be the real individual Satoshi or part of the group Satoshi (partial list to be updated):*

Len Sassaman - technologist and information privacy advocate. Len died on 07/03/2011
https://evanhatch.medium.com/len-sassaman-and-satoshi-e483c85c2b10

Hal Finney - cypherpunk developer and early Bitcoin contributor. Here is a tweet from Hal from 01/10/2009 that says he is "Running Bitcoin" https://twitter.com/halfin/status/1110302988. Hal died on 08/28/2014

John Forbes Nash Jr. was an American mathematician who made fundamental contributions to game theory
This simple handwritten letter with mathematical proof, predates modern cryptography and computational complexity theory by decades
https://twitter.com/elinor_c_ostrom/status/1547818169758232580?t=DAHTjTj2lwVI-RFJZfYV1A&s=19
He also predicted the internet and decentralized protocols in 1954:
https://twitter.com/markgoodw_in/status/1583268325412380672?s=20&t=HyT_lwqBENtrzZF0NuB43Q
John died on 05/23/2015.
Big thread with support for Nash being Satoshi 
https://twitter.com/markgoodw_in/status/1584011996936097792?t=bdH8nW1iNvFeuLkVoE_Naw&s=19

Alan Greenspan - American economist who served five terms as the 13th chair of the Federal Reserve in the United States from 1987 to 2006. He sounds like a Bitcoiner here in his paper: https://www.math.snu.ac.kr/~hichoi/finmath/AlanGreenspan-GoldEconomicFreedom.pdf. Alan is still alive.

Craig Wright (FRAUD) - Australian computer scientist and businessman. He actually claims he is Satoshi but can't prove it. Lost lawsuit against hodlonaut in 2022.
Debunking thread: https://twitter.com/jimmy007forsure/status/1572754750877011968?s=20&t=q_tW6mmwyQfQADJmkhBlSQ
Debunking podcast: https://anchor.fm/dr-bitcoin

Aliens (advanced civilization) or time-traveler . You think I'm kidding? Read this and be sure to read the article presented at the end of it as a follow up (your mind is about to be blown): https://tomerstrolight.medium.com/why-people-wonder-if-bitcoin-is-alien-technology-f9fda5b018b

National Security Agency (NSA): 
Since they are well versed in cryptography and created SHA-256

Pete Rizzo proposed that Julian Assange (WikiLeaks) is Satoshi. Julian is still alive but held in captivity.

Other possible identities - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satoshi_Nakamoto

- 17 brilliant quotes by Satoshi Nakamoto, the creator of Bitcoin: https://coindiligent.com/interesting-quotes-satoshi-nakamoto

Satoshi's quotes organized by topic by <@456226577798135808> 
https://www.satoshivibes.com

https://satoshi.nakamotoinstitute.org/

"The Complete Satoshi"
Everything Satoshi did and said between 2008 and 2012 is indexed here. Wow.
https://satoshi.nakamotoinstitute.org/

The Japanese translation of Satoshi Nakamoto is as follows:
Satoshi = to enlighten
Naka = inside
moto = book
Put it all together: Inside the book, there is a force that enlightens us.

An online profile for the pseudonymous creator of Bitcoin, Satoshi Nakamoto, includes an auspicious birthday of April 5, 1975.

Eighty-eight years ago on April 5th, the United States Federal government issued Executive Order 6102, making citizen’s private ownership of gold illegal. This egregious overstep of government-mandated monetary policy is, coincidentally, the chosen date of Satoshi Nakamoto’s birthday, according to the verified profile for the pseudonymous creator of Bitcoin on the P2P Foundation Forums. It isn’t by accident that the profile reflects this date; Satoshi also chose the year as 1975, the year in which Executive Order 6102 was cancelled.
- https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/today-bitcoins-satoshi-nakamoto-turns-46-2021-04-05
"Satoshi" written in Japanese Kanji. Meaning: first word means wise sage philosopher, second word means chronicler of history/time
https://twitter.com/isabellasg3/status/1517660909128364034?t=T-zlfqsICWrE1Ba2KyvIXw&s=19

What the people think
https://twitter.com/TheRealPlanC/status/1534244021459116033?t=OSyat14Vu2RUpJdU3IB-xQ&s=19

In an online profile, he said he lived in Japan. His email address was from a free German service. Google searches for his name turned up no relevant information; it was clearly a pseudonym. But while Nakamoto himself may have been a puzzle, his creation cracked a problem that had stumped cryptographers for decades. 
- https://www.wired.com/2011/11/mf-bitcoin/

On a bitcoin IRC channel, someone noted portentously that in Japanese Satoshi means "wise." Someone else wondered whether the name might be a sly portmanteau of four tech companies: SAmsung, TOSHIba, NAKAmichi, and MOTOrola. It seemed doubtful that Nakamoto was even Japanese. His English had the flawless, idiomatic ring of a native speaker.
Perhaps, it was suggested, Nakamoto wasn't one man but a mysterious group with an inscrutable purpose—a team at Google, maybe, or the National Security Agency. "I exchanged some emails with whoever Satoshi supposedly is," says Hanyecz, who was on bitcoin's core developer team for a time. "I always got the impression it almost wasn't a real person. I'd get replies maybe every two weeks, as if someone would check it once in a while. Bitcoin seems awfully well designed for one person to crank out."
Nakamoto revealed little about himself, limiting his online utterances to technical discussion of his source code. 
- https://www.wired.com/2011/11/mf-bitcoin/
